clean_content:
Definition / general

* Common premalignant alteration, usually of the lower lip vermilion, that results from chronic ultraviolet light exposure

Essential features

* Clinically, this manifests as blurring of the demarcation between the vermilion and lip mucosa ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:899](32077056))* Actinic cheilitis has a strong predilection for fair skinned (> 87%) men (> 70%) over the age of 55; colloquially known as farmer's lip or sailor's lip due to its association with such outdoor occupations ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:899](32077056), [AOCD: Actinic Cheilitis [Accessed 4 March 2024]](https://www.aocd.org/page/ActinicCheilitis))* Surface epithelium is variably dysplastic and is low risk for malignant transformation ([J Investig Clin Dent 2018;9:e12343](29863311), [StatPearls: Actinic Cheilitis [Accessed 4 April 2024]](31855380), [J Dent Res Dent Clin Dent Prospects 2021;15:285](35070184))
      + Hyperkeratosis, acanthosis and atrophy of the epithelium may also be present* Underlying connective tissue exhibits solar elastosis, which appears as a band of amorphous, acellular, basophilic change due to ultraviolet light induced degeneration of collagen and elastin fibers ([Head Neck Pathol 2021;15:566](33372240))

Terminology

* First described as "scurfy, scaly lip of the outdoor worker" by Montgomery and Culver in 1920, who attributed this to effects of wind and weather; Ayres coined the term chronic actinic cheilitis in 1923 to describe a chronic inflammatory disorder of the lips as a result of actinic or chemically active rays of sunlight ([JAMA 1923;81:1183](https://doi.org/10.1001/jama.1923.02650140027010))* In 1997, Manganaro, Will and Poulos designated actinic cheilitis as a premalignant, irreversible pathosis that most often affects the lower lip vermilion ([Gen Dent 1997;45:492](9515418))

ICD coding

* ICD-10: [L56.8](https://www.icd10data.com/ICD10CM/Codes/L00-L99/L55-L59/L56-/L56.8) - other specified acute skin changes due to ultraviolet radiation* ICD-11: [EK90.Y](https://icd.who.int/browse/2024-01/mms/en#1574420820%2Fother) - other discrete epidermal dysplasias

Epidemiology

* Actinic cheilitis has a strong predilection for fair skinned (> 87%) men (> 70%) over the age of 55 ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:899](32077056))

Sites

* Actinic cheilitis affects the vermilion of the lower lips in 95% of cases ([Head Neck Pathol 2020;14:899](32077056))

Pathophysiology

* Ultraviolet B (UVB) rays (290 - 320 nm) are the primary cause of actinic damage as 70% is absorbed by the skin ([J Oral Med Oral Surg 2023;29:30](https://doi.org/10.1051/mbcb/2023029))
  + This form of radiation drives thymine and uracil dimer formation in DNA and RNA, respectively; additionally, UVB rays create 6 - 4 pyrimidine photoproducts and substitutions of cytosine thymine in DNA, which particularly results in mutations to the p53 protein ([Photochem Photobiol 2008;84:422](18248501))

Etiology

* Ultraviolet radiation from long term sun exposure

Clinical features

* Actinic cheilitis manifests as a blurred demarcation between the vermilion and the mucosal lip, erythema and edema with subsequent dry scaling / a persistent, nonmigrating crust and in some cases, leukoplakia ([BDJ Open 2017;3:17016](29607086), [J Drugs Dermatol 2011;10:1240](22052302))
  + Patients typically have a chief concern of persistent chapped lips or lip tightness ([AOCD: Actinic Cheilitis [Accessed 4 March 2024]](https://www.aocd.org/page/ActinicCheilitis))

Diagnosis

* May be detected clinically as blurring between the vermilion and lip mucosa as an incidental finding
  + Lip may also be erythematous, swollen or present with white patching* Biopsy is indicated

Prognostic factors

* Chronic sun exposure without protective measures increases risk for malignant transformation* Weighted remission rate following surgical treatment (92.8%) is greater than nonsurgical treatment (65.9%)
    + Additionally, the recurrence following surgery (8.4%) is lower in comparison to nonsurgical treatment (19.2%) ([Oral Dis 2019;25:972](29908101))

Case reports

* 51 year old man with a chief concern of a lip lesion that was diagnosed by his dentist ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 2020;130:e203](https://doi.org/10.1016/j.oooo.2020.04.441))* 64 year old, fair skinned man with multiple crusted areas of the lower lip vermilion ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radiol 1980;50:21](6930597))* 67 year old woman with a 2 year history of dryness, thickening and scaling of the entire lower lip that was treated with photodynamic therapy ([Phtodermatol Photoimmunol Photomed 2007;23:209](https://doi.org/10.1111/j.1600-0781.2007.00299.x))* 76 year old man presented with a white, hyperkeratotic lesion of the lower lip ([Dermatology 2016;232:1](27513668))

Treatment

* Surgical treatments, particularly carbon dioxide laser ablation and vermilionectomy, are associated with the most favorable outcomes and the fewest recurrences ([J Eur Acad Dermatol Venereol 2021;35:815](33251620))* Nonsurgical treatments for actinic cheilitis consist of a variety of topical therapies, including
    + 5-fluorouracil+ Imiquimod+ Trichloroacetic acid+ Ingenol mebutate+ Diclofenac* Reference: [Photodermatol Photoimmunol Photomed 2019;35:11](30066408)

Clinical images

Contributed by James Guggenheimer, D.D.S.  

[![Blurring of lip vermilion](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGuggenheimer01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGuggenheimer01.jpg)

Blurring of lip vermilion

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Surface epithelium is variably dysplastic* Hyperkeratosis, acanthosis and epithelial atrophy may be noted* Underlying connective tissue exhibits solar elastosis, which appears as a band of amorphous, acellular, basophilic change due to ultraviolet light induced degeneration of collagen and elastin fibers ([Head Neck Pathol 2021;15:566](33372240))* Chronic inflammatory cell infiltrate and dilated blood vessels are often present

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Joshua Seth Goldfaden, D.D.S.  

[![Hyperkeratotic, dysplastic epithelium](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden01.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden01.jpg)

Hyperkeratotic, dysplastic epithelium

[![Prominent solar elastosis and telangiectasia](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden02.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden02.jpg)

Prominent solar elastosis and telangiectasia

[![Epithelium with dysplastic changes](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden03.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden03.jpg)

Epithelium with dysplastic changes

[![Arising squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden04.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden04.jpg)

Arising squamous cell carcinoma

[![Keratosis and solar elastosis](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden05.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden05.jpg)

Keratosis and solar elastosis

[![Epithelial dysplasia and dilated vessels](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden06new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/oralcavityactiniccheilitisGoldfaden06new.jpg)

Epithelial dysplasia and dilated vessels

Positive stains

* [p53](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp53.html) is variable; may have extreme (loss or gain) staining of surface epithelium or may be nonextreme (nonmutated)
  + [MDM2](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsMDM2.html) coexpression may also be increased ([Oral Oncol 2008;44:878](18234540))* [Ki67](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainski67.html) and [IMP3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsIMP3.html) may exhibit respective increased proliferation and expression within surface epithelium ([Oral Maxillofac Surg 2022;26:587](34817714))

Negative stains

* [SOX10](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainssox10.html), [MelanA / MART1](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmart1.html), [MITF](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsmitf.html) and [HMB45](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainshmb45.html)

Sample pathology report

* Left lower lip, incisional biopsy:
  + Actinic cheilitis (see comment)+ Comment: Actinic cheilitis is considered a premalignant condition. Long term monitoring is advised. Further, the patient should be cautioned against future unprotected sun exposure and smoking (if applicable) ([Oral Surg Oral Med Oral Pathol Oral Radol and Endodontol 1999;88:181](10468463)).

Differential diagnosis

* [Squamous cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumornonmelanocyticscc.html):
  + Invasive tumor islands are seen within the connective tissue+ Abnormal mitotic figures and keratin pearl formation may be seen* **Cheilitis glandularis:**
    + Inflammatory condition of the minor salivary glands and excretory duct dilation, particularly of the lower lip+ Nodular enlargement, reduced mobility and eversion of the affected lip(s) ([J Am Dent Assoc 1989;118:317](2921430))* [Basal cell carcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/skintumornonmelanocyticbcc.html):
      + Nests of basaloid cells with peripheral palisading associated with a fibromyxoid stroma
        - Basaloid cells have a high N:C ratio with hyperchromatic nuclei* **Herpes labialis:**
        + Intraepidermal blisters with acantholytic epithelium and solitary keratinocytes within the blister pouch
          - Nuclei of the keratinocytes show nuclear changes, including margination of chromatin, multinucleation and nuclear inclusions- Nuclear viral inclusions are small, pink deposits with a clear halo+ Initial clinical lesions appear as blisters that rupture and ulcerate+ The condition is self limiting and recurrences may occur
